Participants responses in the study by Harrison et al., "Ranking Visualizations of correlation according to Weber's law"

Source: R/vis_correlation.R
vis_correlation2.Rd

A dataset containing each individual responses of the participants. In this study, participants were asked to make multiple judgements about the correlation in multiple blocks. This dataset contains each judgement by each participant.

Format

A data frame with 275,976 rows and 11 variables:

rbase

The coefficiant of correlation using which the stimuli was generated

rv

The actual coefficiant of correlationshown to participant

approach

Above or Below. indicating that the reference value of r was compared to values of r above it in the staircase procedure; or from below, indicated it was compared to values of r below it

correctChoice

L or R. What was the correct choice

currentChoice

L or R. What was the choice selected by participant

gotItRight

TRUE or FALSE. Whether the participant was correct or incorrect

jnd

Just Noticeable Difference value for the trial

index

Trial number within a block for each participant

participant

Participant identifier

vis

Type of visualization used

rdirection

The direction of the slope of the line (positive or negative)

References

Pierre Dragicevic, Yvonne Jansen, Abhraneel Sarma, Matthew Kay and Fanny Chevalier. (2019). "Increasing the transparency of research papers with explorable multiverse analyses." *Proceedings of the 2019 CHI Conference on Human Factors in Computing Systems* pp. 1-15.

Kay, Matthew, and Jeffrey Heer. (2016). "Beyond Weber's law: A second look at ranking visualizations of correlation." *IEEE transactions on visualization and computer graphics* 22.1: 469-478.

Lane Harrison, Fumeng Yang, Steven Franconeri, and Remco Chang. (2014). "Ranking visualizations of correlation using Weber's law." *IEEE transactions on visualization and computer graphics* 20.12: 1943-1952.

Contents

Developed by Abhraneel Sarma, Michael Moon, Matthew Kay.
